Step 5. Turn to a new dirction you havent faced yet.
Step 6. find the vanishng point on that new horizon (C)
Step 7. about face 180 degrees
Step 8. find the vanishing point on that new horizon. (D)
Step 9. draw CD with the intersection of AB and CD as E
Step 10. bisect angle AEC with RAY EF where F is the vanishing point on the horizon.
Step 11. rotate your body so you are facing your original vanishing point you are Facing A and bisecting line AB at point G

Your vector is Line GA with the direction of EF. , as long as your eyeball does not move, or you move, every point you see will have the vector of GA with a direction that is determined by other objects along the horizon.

In C++ programming language, there's a mistaken name that the container in the standard library is named "vector".
As a programmer, I don't think vectors are seen as lists (lists here mean a linear and ordered data structure, not linked list) by anyone, `std::vector` is just a wrong name and have no any relation with vector. Usually, you'll find "real" vectors and matrices in some codes about rendering, etc; for example, to render the game in the window, you have to do some linear transformations according to the camera (the player's character's eyes if it's a first person) for the positions.
The mathematicians perspective: a vector is anything that behaves like a vector.

IT guys, storage guys, scripting guys, and mathematicians are always "him." I realize that the male is meant to represent male and female, but I know that even I generally picture a man when I think mathematician, physicist, astronomer, IT guy, etc. So I hope in future videos you might consider using she for your generic tech person, or a neutral pronoun. you know why the animation of the vector stepping at 5:08 bothers me? because I want it to be the Pythagorean formula. Where the hypotenuse of a right triangle equals the sum of the squares of the two sides. But it is the way it is in the animation...because for all intents and purposes you're right. Stepping first in the direction of the x-axis vector and then in the direction specified by the y axis vector DOES achieve the same ENDPOINT as if we had traveled along the hypotenuse. And if we are teleporting from point to point, or generating computer graphics that only care about how we visualize the endpoint...sure. There is no reason not to treat the matrix of vectors as equivalent to the endpoint. But to me, the animation is head-splitting, because you're asking me to visualize two identical triangles for two identical formulas, it feels...like a space paradox. It also feels like something worth noting as potential confusion for those of us with less common sense or logical intuition or whatever. Like, the distance of that path cannot be equal to the distance of the hypotenuse, only the squares of that distance can be equal to the square of that hypotenuse. Or something. I should go review that before I post this. But it doesn't matter, because we aren't talking about distance in space, we are talking about vectors, the point of calling them something different from lines, the reason we have special words for this, is self-evident. We need to distinguish outlines from lines that just describe invisible motion, lines that describe motion through time...is that what a vector is? Motion through time? and that's just hard to keep in the back of my head when I look at this. I don't need to care about the distances because the goal of this math is to represent the scaling of points, not worry about the lengths of imaginary lines.

I've then concluded that a 3D vector has opposite, adjacent & upward components, then I've envisioned two vectors & according to the idea of "torque"/moment, the x component of one vector acts as a perpendicular force to the y component of the other vector thus moving it anti-clockwise (making a +ve torque/turning effect)
& Then that y component of the same vector conceptually acts as a perpendicular force onto the z component of the other vector thus causing a turning effect in the clockwise direction (ie -ve torque/turning effect, if you think of it in terms of the screw rule, thus the -ve we have when doing a 2×2 matrix),
Lastly the x component acts as a force in the direction of the other x component of the position vector, thus causing no turning effect as they're parallel. (Try drawing that)
Do it over again ABOUT the z & y also, & now you get a 3D determinant.

Taking advantage of spherical polar co-ordinate system:
It's magnitude:
1. |v|

It's orientation:
2. α (angle in x-y plane)
3. β (angle from the z axis)

It's position in spacetime but using spherical polar co-ordinates:
4. ρ (distance from origin)
5. θ (to determine it's longitude)
6. φ (to determine it's latitude)
7. t (time)

All I knew, was that a vector would point in a direction, and its length represented a magnitude.  That was about it, due to having dropped out of school.  The only other thing that stood out in my mind years later was the Pythagorean theorem.  These few memories turned out to be hilarious.  Why ???  Well, in my spare time I continued to analyze "Motion", because I had noticed something odd about it.  My first simple analysis of motion had led me to a motion paradox.  Eventually I did solved the paradox.  Via the use of motion vectors, simple length scalars, and the Pythagorean theorem, I then converted my new understanding of motion, into equations.  I then checked some physics books and found that my equations were identical to Einstein's Theory of Special Relativity equations, and the Lorentz Transformation equations.  However, the way in which I derived these equations, has apparently not been thought of by anyone else up to this date. The next thing that I discovered was that if I mention this achievement on YT, I get all sorts of rude responses.  I was proud of my accomplishment, especially considering the fact that I had slowly fell into a semi-coma over an 8 year period, and then spent another 8 years recovering and re-learning once the cause was discovered.  And, not to forget, I also had a head injury at age 10, which took me from being 2nd or 3rd in my class, to dropping to the bottom, and later on then actually failing grade 8.  So, overall, I am totally disgusted at the oh so many negative responses that I have received.

In computer science, a vector is one dimensional (a LINE of elements).
To make it two dimensional, you need a vector of vectors. Also called a matrix (a SQUARE of elements).
And a vector of vectors of vectors is a three dimensional vector (a CUBE of elements).

This is because the dimensionality here refers to the structure of the data, not to the meaning of the data.

For the computer science student perspective I prefer to say that the order is arbitrary, but that the consistency of the order is not. So that numbers representing the same categorical data also occupy the same position in the vector, but beyond their coordination the actual position representing each category in the vector is arbitrary. This arbitrariness is similar to whether you treat matrices as row major or column major, so long as your choice is consistent. That we take them as column major is more a matter of convention than mathematical necessity.

I think the way you described the computer science student's idea about vectors is just about overloaded terminology. I doubt that a CS student would look at you in the eye and call a list the same thing as a mathematical vector, it's just that the term has two distinct meanings. It's like how "functor" means totally different things in C++ vs. Haskell vs. SML/OCaml, where the terms are in some fundamental ways related (being some kind of high-level mapping), but they refer to totally separate concepts that people wouldn't confuse with each other. You can easily fit all those different definitions into your head without confusing two or three of them, and I think that's what it's like with the different definitions for vectors.
